Award.AwardTitle: Understanding Human Responses to Environmental Change Using a 2,500-Year Reconstruction of Paleoecologic and Socioeconomic History

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how past societies responded to climate change. There is a general sense that modern societies are more insulated than pre-industrial societies from the effects of climate change, but this may not prove to be true. Developing a more complete understanding of how natural and human-caused changes affected the environment in the past can potentially guide decisions aimed at promoting future sustainability. Physical scientists often view abrupt changes in past climate as the primary cause for societal collapse; however, social scientists argue that sociopolitical decisions contribute to environmental change, and we should not study societal vulnerability without including an analysis of social structures. This project will integrate paleoenvironmental reconstruction with socioeconomic history to identify linkages between social and environmental change associated with climate variability. The research team includes paleoecologists, geologists, social historians and archeologists who will investigate a site near Rome, Italy that has been continuously utilized for over 2,300 years. The team will analyze medieval literature and property maps preserved in the archives of local monasteries, municipalities and the Vatican to obtain written "eye-witness accounts" of landscape change to help reconstruct the socioeconomic history of the region. In addition, the team will analyze physical evidence from lake sediments, including forest history from pollen, flood and erosion history from paleomagnetism and sediments, lake history from diatoms, temperature from oxygen isotopes, and fire history from charcoal analysis. By comparing the timing of significant environmental changes in the paleoenvironmental reconstruction to the timing of social history from written records the team will be able to suggest whether environmental change was caused by humans, by climate, or some complicated interaction of the two. In cases when climate change appears to have resulted in socioeconomic collapse, the research team will explore different models of socio-political structures that influenced how the local population was able to respond to the crisis.

Insights from this work will contribute to our understanding of actions that may guide policy decisions that better prepare communities for sustaining their local environment when faced with climatic change. The project will contribute to K-12 education by providing professional development to high school teachers of science, history and social studies. These teachers will create cross-disciplinary lesson plans that meet science curriculum standards and be disseminated to educators throughout the country using the Nevada Data Portal. Three graduate students will be supported while they earn advanced degrees in Geography (PhD), Geological Sciences (PhD) and Education (MA). These students will gain international experience, working with Italian researchers and graduate students. Six undergraduate students will also be supported as well as one early career female research scientist. This project will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups by both recruiting students from these groups, as well as working with high schools in communities with large populations of underrepresented groups. This project will advance scientific knowledge by creating a high resolution record of environmental change in the heart of the Roman Empire, a region that has been central to advances in western culture for thousands of years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the human response to environmental change over the last 2,500 years. The research included analysis of physical environmental data preserved in lake sediments (fossil pollen from plants, geochemical signals, and fossil aquatic organisms) as well as analysis of historical documents from archives. The work was done in central Italy where there are very long written records of human activities, as well as detailed archaeological studies for the pre-historical period. The most significant finding was that since the Roman period, there have been five major changes in the landscape; periods when the forest changed to such an extent that it was clearly visible in the fossil record. Furthermore, in most cases, the timing of these changes coincided most directly with human socioeconomic changes, rather than abrupt climatic change. For example, at the end of the Roman period, historical and archaeological evidence indicate there was a dramatic decline in population, and historians have assumed that forests expanded in response, but our evidence shows that instead, forests declined, both in abundance and tree diversity. We think this happened because although there were fewer people, the new political regime relied heavily on wood products (rather than stone and ceramic like the Romans) and the trade network sustained during the Roman Empire, had collapsed, meaning that the local population placed greater reliance on extraction of local forest products, reducing forest abundance and decreasing forest diversity by selectively cutting specific tree types. We also found that changes in laws governing land ownership and use led to rapid loss of forest after Charlemagne’s conquest of central Italy. This happened near the beginning of a period called the Medieval Warm Period, when the region began to be warmer and drier. The socioeconomic changes that promoted agricultural intensification led to widespread clearing of forest for farming and pasture, and the warmer climate likely allowed for the upslope expansion and persistence of the new land use practices. A reversal of this climatic trend, with the beginning of the Little Ice Age, combined with loss of population following the Black Plague, and local political instability, led to widespread land abandonment and rapid return of forest. After about 200 years of reduced human land use, the forest had nearly returned to its original state, but during the modern period, new forest laws and land use practices have created a forest that is completely different from any of the forest types seen over the previous 2,500 years.

 Our study has implications for modern forest restoration efforts. We cannot assume that the forests we see today are the result of only ecological and climatic processes. Human land use practices have resulted in significant changes in the diversity and structure of our forests, and if we do not understand the role that humans have played in structuring modern forests, we cannot fully restore forest ecosystems to their previous conditions. Modern forests are the result of a long history of land use, as well as modern socioeconomic priorities that control land management today. The most successful restoration efforts will include teams of ecologists, paleoecologists, historians, archaeologists and social scientists working together to explore the full range of factors that have contributed to changing forest dynamics through time. We also took advantage of recent earthquakes near our site to explore the potential for reconstructing past earthquakes using geochemical signals in lake sediments. Our results show some promise in the ability to identify past earthquakes. These findings provide seismologists with one more tool for understanding the history of earthquakes in populous regions of the globe.

This project included eight middle school and high school teachers who were involved in summer field research and workshops and developed science lesson plans that were integrated into science, social science, math and English courses. Over one hundred middle school students were also involved in a project-based learning curriculum centered on how they can use the methods from this research project to investigate the environmental history of the wetland adjacent to their school. Results of the project-based learning component were presented at an international science conference. Four PhD students were supported under this project resulting in four dissertations. Fifteen faculty and research scientists from seven different universities and research institutes in the United States and Italy collaborated in this research. So far, nine peer-reviewed articles have been published in international scholarly journals, and more than twenty-five presentations have been made at professional conferences, public forums, and educational institutions.
